body: PG4#154 is green
Great. I expect i can get this in tomorrow.

@pritidesai 
Hi Priti. Based on the comments above, we have two features to be implemented in this PR. 

The first one is to simply pull all the binaries available for mac, ubuntu and windows on the releases page.

The second one is to build openwhisk-cli locally. If we run the command "./gradlew distDocker -PcrossCompileCLI=true", all the binaries will be built. If we run "./gradlew distDocker", only one binary will be built to meet the current edge host. We should have a flag to specify the option.
Thanks @akrabat for the comments, I will address them.
Looks much better 😀

Hi @sebgl, thanks for your contribution. Sorry that it took so long to get to this!

This LGTM as it's preserving behavior as noted in the PR.

Rebased to `master`.

When we squash this, please seize all commit messages other than the first (fixup all commits)
Rebased to `master`.

@csantanapr @rabbah pushed to the latest version of ansible, which also includes a move from `docker-py` to `docker` (renamed). The docker lib had a major version update, moving seems desirable for future compatibility.

All pull-requests relative to this epic are open and ready for review. For convenience, here's how they add up:

* #2161 (DockerClientWithFileAccess)
* #2107 (ContainerProxy)

Those two can be reviewed and merged independently. They should be merged before:

* #2151 (ContainerPool)
* #2177 (DockerContainer)

Those two again should be independently review-/and mergeable. After the first two have been merged, the latter should be rebased to incooperate any changes that might apply.

After those 4 requests are in, I'll assemble a final PR which will hook up the ContainerPool + DockerContainer with the invoker as seen in #2021. Note that #2021 is only the "big picture" PR. It does not need to be reviewed nor merged. It only lives there to keep continuous track of our testcoverage and that we didn't introduce regressions.

@rabbah @jeremiaswerner FYI

`wsk property get --cliversion`

probably duplicate of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1492

Word of caution: let's not blindly trade off being scala-idiomatic with being performant. Caveat: I have not read the latest discussion on this. (For example if you end up tail-recursive and cleaner, OK - if not, I'd question the rationale more deeply.)

Hi @Abiwax Which 60 second limit on docker actions are you referring?

60 seconds is just a default.

Actions can run up to 5 minutes for example
```
wsk action create --docker example janesmith/blackboxdemo --timeout 300000
```

Also I would recommend you take a look on using virtualenv to package any 3rd party python libraries in a python zip action, check the docs here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions.md#packaging-python-actions-with-a-virtual-environment-in-zip-files

please re-open the issue if I miss understood your problem
It would also be nice if we could try to expose this info through the CLI page on the download button or near it.
Partially related to #1980 and allowing for more runtime kinds.
@csantanapr We can make for a large set of included python packages, in general, to include a few more popular SDKs. It could make it easier vs venv.

@rabbah 
I agree, I'm more or a nodejs guy and have a good feeling what are the "more popular" libraries to include.

Take into account that we will update to the latest version at our will at any time to keep it current, so users using them should not be surprised when a lib goes from 1.1.0 to 2.2.0 for example.

I'm OK if @rabbah and @cclauss take stab on picking a few popular libs, we can start by matching the nodejs ones but for python.

PS: what about Java and swift? who wants to take on those?
PG4 - 232 running
We should do Java on demand IMO or when we have more data that we've analyzed. For Swift maybe @paulcastro has some initial input on feasibility.

@csantanapr please note that docker actions do not run beyond 60 seconds even with the timeout cap.
Will try the new addition of using virtualenv with python actions instead.
@Abiwax are you doing a blocking invoke? If so, that's true, a request/response must complete in 60s to retrieve the result.
@rabbah yes, the action is part of a sequence.
Are you on slack.openwhisk.org? If so direct message me. If not, I'll ask another question here to clarify.
thanks @rabbah , will join the the slack team now.

hello.rb
```
def main( input )                                                                                                               
  if name = input[ 'name' ]                                                                                                     
    { 'greeting' => "Hello #{name}!" }                                                                                          
  else                                                                                                                          
    { 'greeting' => 'Hello stranger!' }                                                                                         
  end                                                                                                                           
end      
```

Dockerfile
```
FROM ruby:2.4.1                                                                                                                 
RUN  gem install \                                                                                                              
       bundler \                                                                                                                
       sinatra \                                                                                                                
       activesupport \                                                                                                          
       yaml-ostruct \                                                                                                           
       couchrest \                                                                                                              
       jwt        
```

build.gradle
```
ext.dockerImageName = 'rubyAction'                                                                                              
apply from: '../../gradle/docker.gradle'                                                                                        
distDocker.dependsOn ':core:actionProxy:distDocker'
```
Any plan to measure performance?
@markusthoemmes what is the plan for this task? I am interested in knowing the openwhisk performance compared to aws-lambda/google-functions.

Copying my mail from the Apache dev-list for posterity:

Since many have asked I today started an effort to bring a comprehensive performance test suite for OpenWhisk out in the open.

Without much talking, here's the repository: https://github.com/markusthoemmes/openwhisk-performance

My initial idea was to have the tests run on Travis to get comparable numbers. Turns out, the Travis machines are way to weak (especially in terms of CPU cores) to host a whole OpenWhisk system and be able to perform extraordinary good.

The tests I did are based on the npm loadtest module, which is pretty much Apache Benchmark, with a few more features and nicer output. Currently there is only one test which surfaces end-to-end user latency of blocking invocations and maximum throughput. README.md has some more information on how exactly the tests are set up.

I do realize that those tests are the simplest you can get, but that's where I'd like to start. We can get more sophisticated tests any time.

To proceed from here, I'd like to have those tests run on beefier machines, to flesh out the real performance. Any ideas on how to do this in an open-source fashion, e.g. "out in the wild"?

The deletion of the trigger before the feed is deliberate: the contract is the trigger is deleted regardless of whether the feed is terminated correctly (feed action may fail etc. but the trigger is removed nonetheless). Is the pr changing the contract?

@rabbah As usual when you think this is completely reviewed and ready to be merge, just assigned to me and I can click the green merge button :-)

Split this PR into two or address the testing problem, all good to me.
@rabbah please re-review

need to also update `reference.md` to include new package.
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/reference.md#javascript-runtime-environments
`reference.md` updated

This issue was fixed by setting env variables in the docker file. 
 ENV HTTP_PROXY <proxy host>
 ENV HTTPS_PROXY <proxy_host>

I'm getting the feeling your docker/network setup is broken. This doesn't seem a problem with OpenWhisk itself but with the underlying docker system you use.

Can you run the following please:

```
docker run --rm buildpack-deps:trusty-curl wget https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui/archive/v2.1.4.tar.gz
```
@rabbah any more concerns?

Hi, thank you very much for working on this, sounds like an awesome idea.

One important historic bit though: We've kinda build our own tracing using our logs (see the markers we attach to our logs). Those are parseable by, for example, Elasticsearch.

It would be nice to integrate into this and generate as little code overhead as possible as we've been very cautious with instrumenting our code that way.

Other than that: Looking forward to your pull-request. 👍

This is  resolved by adding following changes to the docker file.
RUN export http_proxy=<proxy_host>&& \
    export https_proxy=<proxy_host>&& \
    wget https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui/archive/v2.1.4.tar.gz && \
    mkdir swagger-ui && \
    tar zxf v2.1.4.tar.gz -C /swagger-ui --strip-components=2 swagger-ui-2.1.4/dist && \
    rm v2.1.4.tar.gz && \
    perl -pi -w -e  's{http://petstore.swagger.io/v2/swagger.json}{/api/v1/api-docs}g;' /swagger-ui/index.html
I approved the changes.
@rabbah any more concerns?

I did experiment with a client-side wrapper for actions to enable zipkin support:
https://github.com/jthomas/zipkin-instrumentation-openwhisk

It does work but there are performance issues. This has also been discussed on the mailing list. 
👍  for adding this into the core platform.
cc @adriancole

in order to restore the required `putIfAbsent` atomicity, there are a few options:

1) code directly to ConcurrentHashMap, which offers `putIfAbsent`. this won't be a huge amount of code, but it is new code

2) make a PR against CaffeineCache to expose `putIfAbsent` -- after all, CaffeineCache uses ConcurrentHashMap as its impl. we can't currently do this with a subclass, because the map impl is private. so a PR would either (or both) make the private map protected, and/or add the putIfAbsent method

is it notable that the comments for BasicCache (which is the interface for CaffeineCache) states "A facade for benchmark implementations"? and that Caffeine also offers a more complete BoundedLocalCache impl? which leads to option 3...

3) use BoundedLocalCache (BLC) as our impl, instead of CaffeineCache. BLC offers putIfAbsent. Also, it is possible that we can use BLC for much of our MultipleReadersSingleWriter (MRSW) impl. Not sure yet how much, but initial inspection leads to the guess that BLC does much of what MRSW does?
PG1#1452 is green.

You might be a interested in the [akka-http cache](https://github.com/akka/akka-http/pull/986) that uses Caffeine and is intended to help migrations from Spray. You can also use the asMap() view to get access to methods like putIfAbsent and computations
One proposal is that each feed package could include a "health" or "status" action which, when invoked, returns the kind of information you are asking for.
@ben-manes thank you **so much** for pointing me to `asMap()` 🤕 . Was about to blame Java/Scala interop 😀
My pleasure. It looks like you might also want to use policy() for the ordered keys method. The [migration notes](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/ConcurrentLinkedHashMap) might be helpful.

Damn, small world @jthomas.

One option would be to consider slightly more general-purpose context propagation and deploy Zipkin on top of that, see (work in progress / under submission): https://github.com/JonathanMace/tracingplane

@JonathanMace nice to see you! here or elsewhere we should revisit brave-tracingplane I have some examples of swapping its in-process propagation innards here https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/blob/master/brave/src/test/java/brave/features/log4j2_context/Log4JThreadContextTest.java

else - most recent scala-brave stuff here, though this is not to presume what is best fit for this project https://github.com/bizreach/play-zipkin-tracing mainly the underlying tracer api is better now, so worth a look
fyi I bumped the existing akka project in case they are interested in updating to latest greatest https://github.com/levkhomich/akka-tracing/issues/95

@bjustin-ibm I think we should make sure that all entity names are different. Otherwise I could see those tests failing because a later test grabs an activation from an earlier test because of the fudge factor.

Hi, Sandeep.

so reporting is out-of-band, and I think what you are asking about is
in-band propagation.

propagating across kafka is a bit hairy as john mace will tell you. We do
have folks doing it, but no standard as choices tend to be not great (abuse
keys or coordinate an envelope)

https://gist.github.com/adriancole/76d94054b77e3be338bd75424ca8ba30

wrote:

It looks many people in this thread are big fan of zipkin.
However, one more option could be [pinpoint](https://github.com/naver/pinpoint) which is also based on Google Dapper.
Since core OW components run on JVM, pinpoint could be a good option I think.

AFAIK, main differences between Zipkin and Pinpoint are as follow:

Zipkin requires code changes on core components.
It keeps "context" throughout all call stacks.
That means we should add that "context" arguments to every call.
It makes tracing code is tightly coupled with core logics.

But Pinpoint uses "bytecode instrumentation" so it does not require any code changes on core modules. It intervenes codes to change bytecode at class loading time.


![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3447251/25522874/8026c21a-2c3f-11e7-85d8-f453af3e0fe7.png)

This way, it introduces many advantages.

First, it hides tracing api from core modules. Developers of core modules are not required to care about the tracing codes. Tracing codes are decoupled from core logics.

Second, it`s easy to enable/disable the tracing.
We can easily enable/disable pinpoint tracing logic by just adding/removing jvm startup options.
```
-javaagent:$AGENT_PATH/pinpoint-bootstrap-$VERSION.jar
-Dpinpoint.agentId=<Agent's UniqueId>
-Dpinpoint.applicationName=<The name indicating a same service (AgentId collection)>
``` 

Many languages do not support bytecode instrumentation, but OW is written in scala and running on JVM. It can take advantage of bytecode instrumentation. 

Pinpoints provide plugins for many java libraries such as httpclient, jetty, log4j, logback, thrift, cassandra, gson and so on. But for scala libraries, we need to develop plugin.

Even though we should develop plugins for scala libraries, pinpoint is still a good option I believe.

You can refer to this for more details: [The Value of Bytecode Instrumentation](https://github.com/naver/pinpoint/wiki/Technical-Overview-Of-Pinpoint#the-value-of-bytecode-instrumentation)

ps. I have not caught Zipkin up for a few months. So if I am wrong, kindly correct me : )

I like pinpoint and hyun and folks are earnest and welcome oss folks.

I would say that theres a false dichotomy though. Theres nothing that says
zipkin instrumentation must not use bytecode instrumentation. For example,
we have tossed around some sort of integration between pinpoint and zipkin,
and there is already progress from stagemonitor which also does bytecode
instrumentation.

Regardless, fair and useful chat to see if openwhisk prefers to do bytecode
instrumentation and/or whether pinpoint is a better choice for that or
other reasons. Thats a call folks here should make.

Thanks for asking the hard questions!

Closed #1953
Closed by #2114

> I think we should make sure that all entity names are different

@markusthoemmes I added timestamps to all the entity names to make them unique.

> The clock skew needs to be addressed on the underlying machines

In order to solve this particular problem with better clock syncing, we would have to ensure that clocks never skew by even 1ms, as activation times are recorded in ms. I don't know enough about clock syncing to say for sure but, to me, this doesn't seem practically feasible.
spanner does it :) my point was only to make sure we're also looking at addressing the underlying issue (to a reasonable extent).

yuck.   I'm going to withdraw this PR and look into using lodash instead.
FWIW we do another open PR that would install g++ https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1786/files.
I was thinking installing jq binary using apt-get and a modify version of node-jq but that also works
